tweets.text: @tom_putnam @RussellB1ggs @angling_dreams @UnderwaterMedia @theriverstrust @SaveTheWye @marinagibson25 @AnglingTrust @EnvAgency Not to mention the huge populations of simulian larvae and other algae eaters. They are the rivers filter and the loss of the beds and the invert communities they support excerbates the algal bloom. The Wye is out of sync and now the May bloom suppresses the regrowth of the beds.

@RussellB1ggs @angling_dreams @UnderwaterMedia @theriverstrust @SaveTheWye @bettwsresident @marinagibson25 @AnglingTrust @EnvAgency Spot on. As well as looking pretty and being an indicator of a healthy river, tiny molluscs live in it that help to filter the water and keep it clear.

urls.title: Online Networking Sessions
urls.description: SAQN is pleased to welcome you to our online networking sessions – an informal, regular opportunity to meet others in the community, exchange ideas and find out what’s happening. We know that interdisciplinary working takes time, and we want to offer a space for these interactions to happen ‘little and often’ rather than waiting to meet at an in-person conference. We start our session in Zoom with a series of lightning pitches – just 60 seconds to tell the group about something you’ d be interested in
